#Text=Malachi ben Jacob HaKohen
#Text=Malachi ben Jacob ha-Kohen ( also known as the Yad Malachi ) ( 1695/1700 ? – 1772 ) was a renowned Talmudist , methodologist , and one of the greatest Kaballists of the 18th century . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was a student of the famous kabbalist Rabbi Joseph Ergas , author of the original kabbalistic text known as Shomer Emunim .
#Text=Born in Livorno sometime between 1695 and 1700 , he passed on in the year 1772 [ 2 ] and is considered the last of the great rabbinical authorities of Italy . [ 3 ]

#Text=Praised effusively by his contemporaries and quoted frequently by major halakhic authorities of the 18th and 19th centuries , he served as Rabbi of Livorno , Italy , and apparently lived to an old age .
#Text=A decision by him , dated Nisan , 1732 , and referring to a civil case at Rome , is included in the responsa of Rabbi Isaiah Bassani of Reggio ( Todat Shelamim , No. 11 , 1741 ) .
#Text=During the controversy between Jonathan Eybeschutz and Jacob Emden he sided with the former ( letter of the rabbinate of Leghorn in " Luḥot ' Edut , " p.22 ) .

column1: #Text=He is most famous for his Yad Mal'aki ( 1766-7 ) , a methodological work and compilation in three parts :

#Text=part one contains an alphabetical list of all the rules and technical terms found in the Talmud , with explanations ; part two deals with rules regarding the codifiers ; part three deals with the rules relating to legal decisions , explaining certain general principles of legal responsa .
#Text=Malachi wrote also a liturgical work , Shibḥe Todah ( 1744 ) , containing prayers for the 22d of Shebaṭ , a fast-day instituted by the community of Leghorn .

#Text=In addition to these , Malachi also wrote a Sefer Torah in his own hand which then became an authoritative reference for many details regarding the correct formation of various Hebrew letters . [ 4 ]
#Text=Yad Malachi

#Text=His major work , the ' Yad Malachi ' , first printed in Livorno ( 1766 ) , [ 5 ] and later Berlin ( 1857 ) , was praised by his contemporaries as well as halakhic authorities of later generations .
#Text=Rabbi Yitzchak Shmelkes wrote that : " Every reader of this book will be amazed by the way this living lion , the high priest ... . . dives in the mighty waters , the sea of the Talmud .

#Text= And after much time , the sun shone upon the land ... . with the precious book ' Yad Malachi ' , and as the eyes of servants to the hand of their masters , I have raised my eyes and seen ... " [ 7 ]

column1: #Text=The ' Yad Malachi ' was printed again in the late 20th century , and a new edition with greatly improved fonts , format , and biographical detail was printed in Israel in 2001 .

#Text=In 2016 , Machon Yerushalayim published a critical edition with new typesetting and annotations cross-referencing parallel discussions in other " Klalim " works and highlighting discussions of the author 's writing in later works .
#Text=A third volume containing the author 's commentary on the Torah , responsa , and poetry , was published in 2018 .
